topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/536884bf636872352db10000#post_536884bf636872352db10000
You're using the "appeal to nature" fallacy again. What about "all natural" destroying angel mushrooms? Or "all natural" poison ivy? Or maybe eat "all natural" pufferfish.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/536884bf636872352db10000#post_536884bf636872352db10000
[bq="someguy111"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53688371636872283b4d0000#post_53688371636872283b4d0000
Cheap food is just that though-cheap. Food that's produced by big corporations for the sake of profit and grown in synthetic fertilizers and pesticides and possibly exposed to radiation. Real food, like the kind the human body is supposed to eat, grows naturally with little to no human intervention. Sure we could feed the people of the world the food Americans eat, hut don't be surprised when half of them drop dead from heart attacks from all the saturated fats or develop obesity. [/bq]
You do realize that synthesized food wouldn't have any of these saturated fats, cholesterol and so forth right?  If a food has no contiminates, chemicals, pesticides, no cholesterol, no saturated fats, no chance of allergic reaction, no dangerous substances in it.



Also here's a massive slap to the face:
Most soil in the usa is polluted to some level anyways and especially around cities or places where factories have been and so forth.  Living off the land without actually looking into past owners is actually dangerous.  There has been cases of people getting sick from home gardens after they found out their house was built on a graveyard or such.  You're actually more at risk from home gardens than store bought food.  The reason being is that you could straight up be consuming asbestos or even radioactive material if you're that unlucky.  People have actually died from stuff like this before.  There's a reason why there's so much legal paperwork when it comes to farming.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5368864f63687259f0d40000#post_5368864f63687259f0d40000
That's just an example of selective pressure and natural selection which I would think you would be well aware of.

Trust me, as an outdoorsman I'm well aware of getting food from contaminated areas. I know about pesticide residue, asbestos and arsenic in soil and other general contaminates. That's one reason why I won't eat fish out of Lake MI, especially near the Chicago area. Real food also has naturally synthesized vitamins that cannot be recreated in a lab.

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/536887796368727a83930000#post_536887796368727a83930000
I agree with that. Malaria is natural and plastic is not yet the former is bad and the latter can be used for good. Food on the other hand I am very much against being tampered with; the human body had become adapted to what nature has to offer and to introduce something unnatural like that which in some cases has very little safety testing is not something I want to be a part of.

So thats basically why the growing things in africa barren lads can be a problem, cause it will take time and money to see if the soil they are farming in its safe, cause there is no registered history about the land.[/bq]
Also land reclamation is *INSANELY FUCKING EXPENSIVE!*

Problem with someguy's theory in a nutshell is that if it were to happen,
"Welcome to africa burgers!  We only use locally grown food and raised animals from the reclaimed farmland"
"Can you just give me a small order of fries?"
"Sure, that will be US$300"
